By fostering an open and inclusive work culture, managers can encourage their team members to speak up and share their ideas, even if they are not sure of the answer. This can lead to better decision-making and problem-solving, as well as increased job satisfaction and employee engagement.

As a 45-year-old male South African employee working in a mid-sized company in Johannesburg, I strongly agree that one can be a good manager without having a precise answer to every question that a subordinate may raise about their work. A good manager is not necessarily defined by their ability to have all the answers, but rather by their ability to lead, motivate, and support their team members.

Being a good manager means being proactive, adaptable, and transparent in decision-making. It involves setting clear goals and expectations, providing regular feedback, and fostering a positive work environment where employees feel valued and supported. While it's important for a manager to have some degree of knowledge and expertise in their field, it's equally important for them to be able to communicate effectively, listen actively, and encourage collaboration among their team.

In today's fast-paced and ever-changing business landscape, it's unrealistic to expect any manager to have all the answers to every question that may arise. What's more important is their ability to manage ambiguity, be open to learning, and continuously improve their management skills. By doing so, they can build trust, foster innovation, and create a workplace culture that promotes growth and success.
